comment.text: Two words: Super. Nachos. I'm not usually a fan of fusion, but something about crispy wonton skins smothered in Japanese sriracha mayo and gochujang and a hefty serving of meat (personal preference--bulgogi beef) really really calls my name. The Taiwanese nuggets and Thai tots are also delicious. I've mostly ordered off the street foot/apps menu, so I can't comment too much on the mains. But, I feel like the vibe of this place is more along the lines of beer and a bite to share anyway.

Really good food. I've had the noodle bowls, the chicken, and several appetizers. Very good! Service is always friendly.
Full bar. Has a few games (shuffleboard, darts).
Good meeting place for after work - Close to GT, and not too crowded.

There isn't really any restaurant or bar I can compare Pijiu Belly to. It's a unique Chinese, Korean, Japanese, American mix of menu items paired with American Craft Beer. Truly something for everyone.

The dishes that really standout here are:
Super Nachos w/bulgogi
Fried Pork Belly over rice
Taiwanese Fried Chicken
General Tso's Chicken
Ramen

The Super Nachos aren't exactly nacho chips, they're fried wonton wrappers. That mixed with the all the fixings on a Nacho Supreme but with bulgogi instead of ground beef makes this amazing! It's really filling, I order this as a meal and take half of it home. No one makes this, it is a must try!

Fried Pork Belly over rice. This is awesome! It's got a few pieces of flash fried pork belly with bok choy and rice. Simple, delicious, and again "no one else makes this!"

Taiwanese fried chicken is fantastic! It's salted basil fried chicken chunks.
This is super hard to find in Georgia. It's a staple of Taiwanese snacks and Pijiu Belly's version is as close to it as you'll find to the real thing.

General Tso's Chicken: Pijiu's version uses dark meat and it's a little spicy. Not like the wimpy reheated white meat chunks served at most take out places. 

Ramen - I'm a fan of the Tonkatsu but there are others here to choose from as well. Their broth is delicious and I feel like Pijiu's generous with their noodles as well. Low key awesome ramen spot!

******************************************************
If you're still reading after all this, items worth trying as well:
Fish and Chips
Definitely Spicy Pork Bulgogi over Beef Bulgogi
and of course CHICKEN WINGS! This is Atlanta after all!

Service was commendable- attentive and recommendation reliable. Food confusing as promoted as Korean fusion but notes of Chinese like 5spice on appetizers. Food salty and not much flavor. Ambiance more for the pub but not for young family which consists of our company.

Let's start by saying that Wednesday night is trivia night so if you want a quiet dinner where you won't be interrupted then don't go on Wednesday's. 

The atmosphere is hip and inviting. They have board games and a shuffle board table to play. So if you're waiting or done eating and want to show your friends or date your skills, then have at it. 

I went with a group of 6 friends. Everything went smoothly from ordering our drinks and food. The waiter did forget one of my friends order so he got his food last but the waiter never admitted that he forgot to put in the order. I ordered the favorite Pijiu Burger ($13) and it comes with a side so I order the fries. There were a lot of fries. I also ordered their old fashioned drink ($10) and it was perfect. 

The ramen tasted amazing. However, the egg was a bit over cooked. I would definitely come back because all the portions were very generous.

This place never disappoints. Great food and great service. My favorite ramen spot. We ordered the Bulgogi ramen, rotisserie chicken, brussel sprouts, bugogi bop and spicy garlic shrimp.  Aside from the shrimp being a little too spicy for my wife, everything was great. The chicken was off the chain

Not sure if it's the busiest location but fairly slow when we got here on a Tuesday afternoon.
We were seated quickly at the bar. 

The menu items are quite interesting.
I decided to go the street food route because I wasn't super hungry & their menu selection was a bit interesting.

The Thai tots were pretty good, I elected to not get cilantro on it (I guess I'm one of those people). Basically sweet potato tatter tots with jalapeño & some mayo on top. 

I thought I would really like the Tempura Oden but it wasn't as good as I thought. It was mostly just the fried tempura portion of it, I could barely tell there was any fish in it.

Bulgogi Kimchi Taco was probably one of my top two. Every bit of the taco was good. I wish I ordered this prior but at least now I know for the next time I come back.

I didn't get a photo of the wings but trust me they are also worth getting & of course my other favorite. I elected to go the spicy route but my brother switched it to the sweet sauce & it was a great choice.

Overall good experience there, no happy hour though :(

photos.caption: Street Food portion of the menu as of 7/24/18

comment.text: Overall a bit disappointed by their bap bowls.  Needed more sauce and more flavor overall.  Their fried pork belly bites were quite tasty!
Great food, atmosphere, and service. The pork belly was A1. The drinks were unique and delicious.

Changing my Saturday Brunch around! No  more Biscuits and Eggs today, instead my heart wants to have some Peruvian Fusion! So going back here! The dumplings and the fried rice definitely won me over. The chicken was definitely not too dry like a lot of other places so I enjoyed the juiciness. You'll get an American, Asian and Peruvian taste in their food. The price is also reasonable so it's a win win!

I usually frequent this spot solely for the ramen because it is really tasty. They add brussels sprouts to the ramen and though it's different but compliments their tonkutsu broth. They have a Prosecco on tap that I really like as well. Nice beer specials and brunch on the weekends! Servers are supppper friendly and ON POINT!

Came in to Atlanta & had to stop at Pijiu Belly after seeing them on Diner Drive-Ins & Food was delicious we started with the spicy garlic wings which were off the chain & the shrimp dumplings. For our main course we each had the Tonkatsu Ramen (extra spicy) it was something out of world.

photos.caption: Tebasaki wings had the spicy garlic ones instead & they were delicious

comment.text: Great selection of food, excellent staff and a solid location for large groups with different food tastes.

Solid offerings, good comfort food. Bento box lunch specials are affordable ($10-15). Wasn't super impressed by flavors, the tofu was a bit overfried and the chicken was bland (not marinated, seemed to be cooked that slathered in sauce). But all things considered, I will go back again. Their fried chicken and chicken specials looked good. Seems like a great place to share a beer with friends or watch a sports game.

Went here on our last day in Atlanta.  It was suggested by our Uber driver.  Already had planned to go since it was on Diners Drive Ins and Dives.  This was our 55th.  It was very good.  We went about 2pm on Sunday.  No wait, though it was busy (always a good sign).  The food did not disappoint.  My son ordered the Rotisserie Chicken and waffles (he gets this dish everywhere he can).  He loved it.  Even liked the BBQ sauce (he normally doesn't like it).  He wanted to have it shipped to our home.  My fiancé and I listened to the waiter and ordered the Yangnyeom Chicken and Crispy Braised Pork Belly sandwich.  My fiancé also had the Kentucky Joe- coffee and bourbon.  The chicken was one of the best dishes I've had in my life.  I would eat it every day!  This place is a must...so many dishes I wanted to try but can only eat so much at a time!  I'd go back today if I wasn't in New Jersey!

photos.caption: Yangnyeom Chicken: Whole rotisserie chicken chopped and then wok-tossed in spicy gochujang sauce; served with mu and jasmine rice
Crispy Braised Pork Belly: Oven braised for hours then flash fried until crispy and smothered in a peach hoisin sauce

comment.text:
Friends have said this place was super good, and so it seemed like a worthy place to try out with friends. I found it to be just okay: right around 3 1/2 stars.

I originally wanted the jellyfish salad and bulgogi kimchi tacos but changed my order since the jellyfish salad was out. I guess it's popular. Instead, I ordered the Piju Belly burger (rec by a member of our group). 

I found the burger to be sort of plain with only the slightest of slight kimchi pieces and sriracha mayo. The burger was thick and juicy, but at the end of the day, it was just a burger in my mind. The fried egg was an interesting twist to the burger though. Apparently the burger came with a free side so I choose the cold Yakisoba noodles, which was good.

The complimentary appetizers brought out by the owner bc we had a friend who knew him made me super full:

Poutine: I don't know what to say about this as the teriyaki sauce (interesting Asian twist) made the fries super soggy and messy. I'd have to say no to this dish and don't rec you ordering it.

Pijiu's super nachos: The nachos were good, but the fried wonton skins were way too crispy. It was good, but was it really worth $14?! I'd say it's a great sharing plate (or even as the main entree for lite eaters). Overall, it was yummy.

Some other items I sampled from friends worthy of a mention:

Sweet corn cheese: I'd say this is your typical sweet corn smothered in cheese. If you like this elsewhere, you'll like it here.

Taiwanese nuggets: The nuggets were pretty tender and juicy. I'd have to say it's pretty delish. There were various dipping sauces that were available that I didn't get to try. Friends seemed to oo and ah as they sampled it.

Pork belly bowl: The roasted pork belly was huge! It was super tender and flavorful as I sampled a small piece from my friend. Aside from the humongous pork belly, the remainder of the dish was rather plain with the bok choy and rice. 

Other tid bits I observed... There was also a free foosball table and something else as entertainment -- sorry that I can't recall. I believe there were darts as well. If nothing else, chill at the bar and have a drink if you're not ready to grab food.

photos.caption: Piju Belly burger with cold Yakisoba noodles.
The back area of the restaurant behind the bar. This was taken from the side seating area along the wall.

comment.text: Amazing. Get the Kung Pao Noodles with Shrimp and the edamame. We came between 4-6 and got the edamame half off. So so so worth every cent. We also got the $6 beer special pitcher which was a darker beer. It was delicious. The bartender was great. You must come here!!

My wife and I have been coming to this place for the past six months and we absolutely love it. The food is awesome the flavors are amazing and the taste is delicious. The overall service is great, the waiter/waitress always greet customers with a warm welcome, the atmosphere has a nice cabin vibe. I love everything about Pijiu Belly and I would recommend this place to everyone!

Pijiu Belly really fills your BELLY!  

I happened upon this restaurant because I was lost.  I looked them up on Yelp and decided to try them out.  I didn't know what to expect because on the outside the restaurant looks like a tiny house turned restaurant but on the inside it's this spacious bar with seating for days.  The decor is really unique to the space and it was super clean.   

The highlight of the space is the food.  They have mastered the affordable lunch that packs a tasty punch.  I ordered the Salmon Lunch Box and was shocked that it was around $10.  Most Salmon dishes run around $15.  But this box had a side of rice, salad, potstickers, and Miso Soup.  All portions were the perfect size and was enough to get me full and happy.  The Salmon was cooked to medium perfection.  It wasn't too tough and it wasn't raw just the way it should be.  

I would totally recommend you come here with your co-workers, friends, and even on a date.  The price point and food is just right for your appetite!
I had the Taiwanese Nuggets, Crispy Pork Belly Bites, Handcut fries and Grilled on A Sticky

This was a first visit.  I wanted to try something seen on Diners, Drive Ins and Dives.  Boy what a great experience.   
Service was awesome!  They really provided great service and selection recommendations.  
Food: We had poutine for our appetizer, which highly recommend. 
I also had Yangnyeom Chicken which could have fed the three of us.  This was also out of this world. 
Atmosphere was great.  The restaurant was very busy and the fun art work made for a conversation and interest.   
The quality of atmosphere, food and service make me a loyal customer for many more visit.

Always my favorite place when I'm in the city and where I want to take friends when they come to town.

The drinks, great. 
The good, delicious. 
The atmosphere, perfect.

Asian fusion is one of my favorite types of food to eat. Pijiu belly is a great spot. I know they do game nights and I think trivia nights so that's cool. I've been here a couple of times  and it is yummy every time. The Pijiu super nachos are amazing and huge. Anything with Bulgogi beef on it is  so good. This place is a good place to hang out with your friends

Pijiu Belly's convenient location in West Midtown and interesting menu of Korean fusion fare made it one of the first restaurants my fiance and I bookmarked to visit when we first moved to Atlanta. However, for one reason or another, we never got around to trying it until very recently. We wish we had not waited so long, as both the food and service here were pretty great. 

Pijiu Belly has typical bar ambiance and boasts a sizeable outdoor patio during warm weather. Though we did not imbibe, beer acts as the main beverage draw here and the draft list carries something for everyone. Our server remained available throughout our meal and made very helpful suggestions in guiding us through the menu. Per his suggestion, we opted for three small plates and split an entree.

Our three small plates captivated our tastes buds the most. The Thai tots offered a smart take on sweet potato tots by pairing them with piquant accompaniments such as spicy mayo, garlic, and jalapeno. The kimchi pork stir fry was pure Korean goodness and brought well stir fried slices of pork and veggies sizzling in a spicy gochujang sauce. Sambal wings, a special that evening, brought seven crisp, meaty bones of intense garlic-chili flavor.

Our entree, Pijiu's specialty chicken, came next. The half chicken comes with two sides which, for us, comprised a simple potato-cabbage-corn hash and kimchi. We found the sides so-so (the hash a bit bland, and the kimchi less funky than I'm used to), but the chicken itself satisfied. The bird is first cooked rotisserie style then flash fried to crisp the skin. The crackly, well flavored skin is the highlight here and lacks the greasiness of most fried chicken. The breast meat ran a little dry but the darker meats remained juicy. 

We left totally stuffed and paid about $45 with tip, which was totally reasonable given the quantity/quality of food and great service. We will certainly be back for more craveable Asian inspired bar food.

We ordered the happy hour special - buy an entree, get street food 50% off. Told our server that's what we were ordering. When the bill came, it was full price. Asked the server to correct it, and he wouldn't.

The crispy pork belly sandwich wasn't as good as I had heard about. It was very fatty, not quite crispy. Wouldn't get again. The cheesesteak was delicious though! I would give that 5 stars by itself, but everything else about the experience was not great.

They've taken the bungeoppang off their menu at my most recent visit and don't seem to offer desert anymore.

Their patio seating is wide and come with a lot of spaces.

I was pretty excited to visit this place after seeing it on Triple D. The signature dish tends to be the chicken but my wife and I were in the mood for something a bit more different. 

We loved our appetizer the cheese curd, teriyaki fries were really good but the actual fries to us were just kinda average. I felt like they need to be more supportive of the cheese and gravy.  

She ordered the Spicy Dumpling Ramen. She really loved it, minus the wasabi dumpling that snuck up on her she loved the flavor of her ramen broth and was so happy! Perhaps better explanation of the dumpling when ordering would be better or make sure to read about the dumplings on the other page of the menu. 

I ordered the Crispy Pork Belly Sandwich with Peach Hoisin Sauce and the Beef Pho. Wow, the peach sauce was awesome the pork belly was yummy, I felt like it could have been a little warmer, perhaps it sat for a few minutes while other things were being made. The Beef Pho was amazing. I didn't realize that i was supposed to put the extra veggies and sauce in the Pho till the end even after the waiter had told me. I'm slow sometimes. 

Great place I can't wait to get back and try other things!!

photos.caption: Cool sign outside. Nice photo op!
Crispy Pork Belly Sandwich with Peach Hoisin Sauce

comment.text: The Thai tots were really good! The burger was decent as well. I like how you can get yakisoba noodles as a side dish. Overall it was pretty good but next time I'd try something other than the burger. Also the outdoor patio area is really nice when the weathers good!

Went here with my daughter and her husband on a Saturday afternoon, and wow ! Amazing, huge portions of Pho so plenty to take home ... steamed pot stickers were amazing ... staff is very friendly. Will be getting this to go in the future
The food was absolutely terrible for us. The chicken was greasy and super crunchy in a bad way.

Wow! A great place to try some Asian fusion street foods. We split 5 items for 4 people, and it was a good amount of food, and didn't break the bank either. The outdoor seating felt comfortable - not too crowded. It was my first time eating at a restaurant in a long time, so that was a big relief. The waiter was so nice and helpful, too. My favorite items were the shrimp and rice dish, and the wonton nachos. I'd love to come back and try more goodies here.

Been here numerous times, just found out that they now have valet parking on weeknights.

On weeknights, with a parking lot of over 15-20 spots, and street parking within one block, why is a pub like this needs valet parking? 

When I have a choice I will always choose not to give my car and keys to a valet. If it means I will never return here, so be it.

photos.caption: On weeknights, with a parking lot of over 15-20 spots, and street parking within one block, why is a pub like this needs valet parking?

comment.text: We saw this place on Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives and I added it to my list of places to try in Atlanta. We got take-out last night and it was probably the best Asian food I've had since I moved here. Usually take-out isn't as good as dining in, but the food was hot and so delicious. We got the Thai tots, Santa Fe chicken egg rolls, kung pao noodle bowl, and general tsos chicken. You know when something is so good you make mmm noises while eating? Yeah, we both kept doing that  ... the portions are also large enough to have leftovers for lunch the next day!

I came to Pijiu Belly for a brunch. This place was pretty interesting as they take a Korean spin on the food and mixes it up. The party that we came was pretty big, so let's just get straight to the food. I ordered the Three Meat Scramble and I got to try out the Pork Belly Egg Benedict, because well everyone ordered it (including the GF).

So I'll keep this short and simple. The Three Meat Scramble? Meh. The dish was drizzled with this mustard sauce that was just completely overpowering. If they laid down on the sauce it would be better. The pork belly egg benedict was basically a farm house type dish. Instead of being served on english muffins, it was served on full hamburger buns. It was massive for a breakfast meal. Definitely worth it.

I think one thing I took away from here was if I were to come back, I would definitely eye the Chicken and Waffles because I saw other tables order it and it looked pretty tasty. So, I think if I were to give you a tip this would be it... If you're at brunch, give that chicken and waffles a look.

I enjoyed Pijiu Belly. Definitely should be a spot to check out if you're looking for brunch.
Delicious food and kind staff - their small plates are delicious and the atmosphere is laid back. They're also accommodating to large groups and have a spacious patio.
Went for goodbye lunch with co-workers. Had the $10 bento box with beef steak and veggie dumplings. Everything from service to good was great!
I literally try to visit Pijiu Belly every single time I am back home in Atlanta. I have never had anything from here that I disliked and the service is always top notch!

Excellent service, food, spice, and a welcoming atmosphere.

We were immediately greeted, seated, appetizers came quickly, waters refilled promptly, and the ramen was fabulous!

I take a quarter star off for hard boiled vs soft boiled eggs for the ramen. Throws the texture off... 

I will absolutely be back to try some of the rice dishes, thank you for a wonderful meal!

Came here for my customary luncheon with my husband, niece and nephew even they're in town. We decided on Pijiu Belly. Getting seated was easy and wait staff were polite. I however was not impressed. 

I'm not a picky eater at all but I didn't get the flavors that I expected. Everyone else just seemed satisfied on a normal level. Nothing too exciting. 

Would I go back, probably, but not because I chose the spot.

Overall a very cool spot that doesn't get too busy on a weeknight.  We were able to reserve a larger table and even with other patrons still felt that service was attentive and that we were able to speak and converse with one another.  The food is definitely top-notch, well-made, and filling.  We had a selection of appetizers and I opted for the cheesesteak which was very good.  

Biggest gripe has to be the forced valet parking, it's completely unnecessary, especially on a weeknight.  There was ample parking and could have easily parked the car myself.

Pijiu Belly is a mood. From the music (R&B), to the ambiance, to the food (delicious)! Went for lunch yesterday and enjoyed every bite. The space was well socially distanced and the service was great. We had the Taiwanese Nuggets (not pictured), the Pork Belly Rice Bowl, and Pork Bulgogi Bop. The pork belly was cooked perfectly! It was full of flavor and so tender. The Pork Bulgogi Bop had a nice warmth to it and was also flavorful. Definitely would go back at any time of the day. I want to try their brunch menu.

Im a big fan of Asian fusion but I always struggle to find one that i LOVE. This? I LOVE. The nachos are probably the best thing I've ever eaten. The crunch from the wonton chips with the sweetness from the steak's marinade with the sriracha and the vegetables... whew. A must try. I don't remember the name of the other thing we ordered but they were mini sweet potato tots with a mayo based sauce. SO GOOD. I really dont think you can go wrong here. Plan on going back so I can try more stuff! 
Liked the atmosphere and the art on the wall too!

Having lunch at Pijiu Belly was better than I expected.  The host allowed us to sit wherever we liked, and was very cordial and patient explaining the menu items.  The bento box with the beef option was what I selected from the lunch menu.  The beef was delightful! It has just the right amount of seasoning and perfectly paired over a bed of shredded lettuce.  The rice was cooked to perfection.  The miso soup was "uniquely" flavored (not to my liking), but it did not take away from the other options in the bento box.  The salad with ginger? dressing was on par with typical appetizer salads, but the fried pork dumplings and dipping sauce were stellar.  All the food arrived hot and fresh.  The decor at Pijiu Belly was as inviting as the food and the people.  Job well done!

Pijiu Belly is an Taiwanese/Korean Asian Fusion restaurant by west midtown. They have a private lot so parking's not an issue. On a weekday evening, they weren't very busy. There is a dining area in the back of the restaurant and a more bar-like hangout area in the front. There's a foosball table and cornhole in the patio area. Seems like it would be a good place to hangout when the weather's nice.

I ordered the Bulgogi bop which is basically is a bowl of brown rice topped with bulgogi chopped kimchi, cabbage, etc. They gave a generous portion of meat! I couldn't finish all my food and brought half of the home for another meal. The owners here are super friendly! They came over to chat after hearing my friend and I talk in Mandarin and were very warm and welcoming.

I'll definitely be back to try other things on their menu!

Will forever recommend this place! Was looking for a place that took reservations in Atlanta for my husband's birthday and the owner, Lenny, really worked with us. Kept up COVID protocols but made sure to take great care of my party! Not to mention the cocktails and food were phenomenal. So glad I found it! Will definitely be back.

Delicious Korean food and great service. Came here on a whim while in the area but will definitely seek out the place again. I'm sure at peak times parking may be an issue as mentioned in other reviews. We had no problem with parking and even if we did it would have been well worth the trouble. Chicken was also delicious according to my wife. Also the owner makes the kimchi, the kimchi is delish.

I ordered the poutine. After having many traditional poutine, this didn't taste that good. Teriyaki sauce on poutine is not that great. I do understand due to COVID they have limited capacity but there is a big wait time to be seated. They are on a limited staff so the service is slow as well.

One of the few Asian themed gastropub you can find inside the Atlanta perimeter that's actually worth going to for decent food.  Normally the Asian eats are up north where the foods are pleasant in pleasanthill.  Pijiu actually means "beer" in mandarin, our server gave us this little bit of trivia info. Their burgers topped with the kimchi gives just enough heat to give it a unique flavor worth trying. This is the second time I tried their ramen noodle. First time was watered down, but the second time I could tell they put a little more love at flavoring their broth. Meat was plentiful as well as noodle content.  

Parking lot is small so it would be better to car pool,  but if you must all drive separately for your large party there is parking across the street. Not sure if they tow or not but I wouldn't risk it during work hours. 

If you're looking for a place to chill with friends over a beer I'd recommend his place as well. Pregame and go watch Atlanta United play over at Georgia tech!
Great food and service is the BEST. The bartender is welcoming and he gives good suggestions on what to order.

Really enjoyed the chicken. It was very messy but they bring gloves and wipes for you. The ramen, was a tad salty. Sweet potato tots and sauce were delicious. Veggie dumplings were homemade and authentic. Lots on the menu to try!
